channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Defies Odds in War With Russia, But Still Has Far to Go
item.description: Ukraine is on the offensive along most of the 600-mile front line, and the Russians are in a defensive crouch. But about one-fifth of Ukrainian territory is still occupied by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near Kherson, this month.

item.title: Ukraine Battles for Control of Key Black Sea Peninsula
item.description: Ukrainian forces are fighting to drive Russia out of the Kinburn Spit, a strategically important sliver of land at the mouth of the Dnipro River.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman seeking a place on an evacuation train in Kherson on Monday.

item.title: UK Starts to Look at Brexit With ‘Bregret’
item.description: Stung by inflation and bracing for tax increases, the country is in the midst of its gravest slump in a generation, leading many to wonder how much the split with the European Union is to blame.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Chester, northwestern England, this month. Among the Group of 7 advanced countries, Britain is the only one with an economy that is smaller now than it was before the pandemic started.

item.title: Outbreaks Test China’s Efforts to Limit the Cost of ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: China wants to fine-tune its stringent pandemic restrictions to reduce the disruption to daily life caused by lockdowns. But officials are still taking few chances.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Security guards dressed in protective equipment at an office building in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Beijing Is Tackling Air Pollution. Why Can’t New Delhi?
item.description: The return of smog season in India’s capital has again left residents asking why nothing has changed. The answer may be largely political.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj, Matt Stevens, John Yoon and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: The India Gate in New Delhi this month. Recent high levels of pollution in Delhi have prompted officials to halt truck traffic, close schools and ask people to work from home.

item.title: Somalia Braces for Famine, Trapped Between Al Shabab and Drought
item.description: The worst drought in 40 years is pushing Somalia to the brink. If it triggers a rare famine declaration, the militant group Al Shabab will also be to blame.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Andrea Bruce
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m begging Allah not to take another baby from me.” Faduma Adan Abdirahman, 33, held tight a newborn son after the death of her 3-year-old daughter, Hawa, in early November.

item.title: Indonesia Rescue Efforts Underway After Earthquake Kills At Least 268
item.description: As workers try to find survivors, rescue efforts have been hampered by power outages and blocked roads in a disaster that has killed at least 268 people and injured more than a thousand.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Rescue workers lifting a body in Cianjur, West Java province, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Indonesia Earthquake Photos Show Wide Damage
item.description: The quake that toppled hundreds of buildings on the island of Java also blocked roads needed to get victims medical help.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers on Tuesday salvaging items from damaged houses following a 5.6-magnitude earthquake in Cianjur.

item.title: Photos from China’s Latest Covid-19 Lockdowns
item.description: Empty streets, shuttered shops, long lines at coronavirus testing sites and other scenes from China as it tries to combat rapidly spreading outbreaks in cities across the country.
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers fumigating manholes in Shenzhen, China, this month.

item.title: South Africa’s Cyril Ramaphosa Wins a Crucial A.N.C. Battle
item.description: President Cyril Ramaphosa emerged well-placed to win a second term as the head of the country’s governing party, although there is much haggling and horse-trading to come.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa is fighting a leadership challenge that represents a crossroads for the governing African National Congress.

item.title: Kamala Harris Promises Support and Denounces China During Philippines Visit
item.description: The vice president accused China of “intimidation and coercion” in disputed waters, as the Biden administration seeks partners to counter Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: During a trip to Palawan, the province closest to the disputed Spratly Islands, Vice President Kamala Harris said the United States stood with the Philippines “in the face of intimidation and coercion,” a remark aimed at China.

item.title: China Factory Fire Kills 38
item.description: Officials say an investigation is underway into what caused the tragedy at the two-story facility operated by a wholesaler of industrial equipment, clothing and chemical products.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: The factory in Anyang, China, on Monday, in this image taken from video footage run by the state broadcaster, CCTV.

item.title: On the Dnipro River at Night, Ukrainian Fighters Ambush Russian Forces
item.description: Ukrainian units plying the Dnipro River venture behind enemy lines under the cover of darkness, carrying out reconnaissance and sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

item.title: Iran Arrests 2 Actresses for Participating in Protests
item.description: World Cup soccer players, movie personalities and other prominent Iranians have shown support for the protests that have engulfed the country.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Jeré Longman
item.media:description: Iranian players standing in pointed silence as their national anthem was played at the World Cup in Doha on Monday.

item.title: Two Explosions in Jerusalem Kill 1 and Wound at Least 13
item.description: The two explosions occurred at bus stops during the morning rush hour in what were believed to be the first bomb attacks on Israeli civilians since 2016.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israeli security forces at the scene of an explosion at a bus stop in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A closer look at the state of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier near Kherson, this month.

item.title: Missiles for Poland May Disrupt NATO’s Stance on Ukraine War
item.description: NATO is determined to help Ukraine battle Russia, but wants no direct part of the war. A new promise of air defense weapons for Poland may make that more complicated.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: An American Patriot surface-to-air missile system at a military training center in Torun, Poland, in October.

item.title: Ukraine Raids Holy Site Amid Suspicion of Orthodox Church Tied to Moscow
item.description: The security services said they searched for spies and weapons at the Monastery of the Caves in Kyiv. Dozens of priests have been arrested since the war began on charges of aiding Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Monastery of the Caves in Kyiv after the Security Service of Ukraine raided the Orthodox Christian monastery and religious complex on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Indonesia’s Death Toll Climbs
item.description: Plus Saudi Arabia defeats Argentina, Australia loses to France and lockdowns spread across China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Yulius Satria Wijaya/Antara Foto, via Reuters
item.media:description: Rescuers carried a body bag through the rubble during a rescue operation in Cianjur, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Hebe de Bonafini, 93, Who Rallied Mothers of ‘the Disappeared,’ Dies
item.description: She was a key force behind a 1970s human rights movement demanding justice from Argentina’s brutal military dictatorship. Her extreme leftist views later made her a polarizing figure.
item.dc:creator: Ana Lankes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo
item.media:description: Hebe de Bonafini, center, in 1979. She and other mothers of people who had disappeared under Argentina’s brutal military dictatorship held a vigil every Thursday at Plaza de Mayo in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Drone Attack Strikes Sevastopol in Crimea, Kremlin-backed Official Says
item.description: After a drone attack in October, Russia temporarily suspended its cooperation with a deal that allowed Ukrainian grain safe passage through the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: The Black Sea seen from Cape Fiolent, outside the Crimean port city of Sevastopol, in 2018.

item.title: Almost Safe, She Returned to Munich and Lost a Bronzino and Her Life
item.description: A portrait by Bronzino that Ilse Hesselberger once owned is coming up for sale, a reminder of the brutality, and twists of fate, that Jews confronted in the Nazi era.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan

item.title: The War With Russia Has Further Divided Orthodox Churches in Ukraine
item.description: The leaders of the central branch of the Orthodox church in Ukraine made a formal break with the hierarchy in Moscow in April.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kyiv Pechersk Lavra monastery after Ukraine’s security service conducted a raid on Tuesday.

item.title: To the Moon
item.description: NASA is on a return mission.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: A portion of the far side of the moon looms large just beyond the Orion spacecraft.

item.title: China’s Grandparents Are Done Babysitting and Ready to Go Viral
item.description: Rapping grannies, crooning 70-year-olds and gamers in their 80s are challenging traditional Chinese views about aging and what it means to have a long and happy life.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: The four members of Glamma Beijing shooting a video in the Chinese capital.

item.title: The Cool, Wild and Very Remote Andaman Islands
item.description: This archipelago in the Indian Ocean offers pristine nature, Indian culture, a glimpse of fascinating communities and some of the most spectacular beaches in the world.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Poras Chaudhary for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chidiya Tapu beach outside Port Blair, the capital of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, is one of the island group’s many beautiful beaches.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A devastating earthquake has killed more than 150 people in Indonesia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Ukraine Remembers Maidan Protests, a Milestone Toward Putin’s War
item.description: In hindsight, protests that began nine years ago and toppled a Ukrainian president were a pivot point in efforts by Vladimir V. Putin to exert Russian control over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antigovernment protests in Ukraine led to the downfall of President Viktor Yanukovych in February 2014.

item.title: In Women and Nonbinary People, Monkeypox Cases May Have Been Missed
item.description: Despite monkeypox fading from public attention, scientists are still learning how it spreads — including without sexual contact or any symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Kholood Eid for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mobile monkeypox vaccine unit in Brooklyn this month.

item.title: Bao Tong, 90, Dies; Top Chinese Official Imprisoned After Tiananmen
item.description: He helped design China’s political reforms in the 1980s and tried to avert the bloodshed that ended the democracy protests. After prison, he became a critic of the party.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Goh Chai Hin/AFP, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Bao in 2011. Before the crackdown in Tiananmen, he was charged with leaking that martial law was coming, an allegation he vehemently denied. He was sentenced to seven years in prison.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Indonesia’s Deadly Earthquake
item.description: Plus Iranian players protest at the World Cup and “Neighbours” will start filming again.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Rescuers searched for survivors in a destroyed house in Cianjur, Indonesia, after the area was hit by 5.6-magnitude earthquake on Monday.

item.title: The Nature Conservancy Buys Insurance to Protect Hawaii’s Coral Reefs
item.description: If worsening coastal storms damage the reefs, the Nature Conservancy will get a payout and use the money to repair the coral — work that state officials can’t afford to do.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: A shallow coral reef in the waters off Big Island, Hawaii.

item.title: 1947: Rail Walkout in Marseilles Halts Traffic
item.description: The number of strikers in the French port city reached 100,000, with thousands of passengers stranded and communication disrupted.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Jacob Zuma’s Release Was Unlawful, South African Court Rules
item.description: The Supreme Court decision raises the possibility that former President Jacob Zuma, who was granted medical parole from a contempt-of-court sentence, may have to return to prison.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Former President Jacob Zuma of South Africa, center, was initially ordered to jail last year for defying an order to appear before a corruption inquiry.

item.title: Netanyahu Awarded Damages After a Predecessor Called Him ‘Mentally Ill’
item.description: The Israeli prime minister-designate, Benjamin Netanyahu, and his family won a libel suit against a former prime minister, Ehud Olmert, but got far less compensation than they had demanded.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu and his wife, Sara Netanyahu, at a campaign event in Migdal Haemek, Israel, in October.

item.title: Powerful Earthquake on Java Kills at Least 162 in Indonesia
item.description: The quake on the nation’s main island, Java, destroyed hundreds of buildings, and officials feared that many people were still trapped beneath the rubble.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:description: Rescue workers lifting a body in Cianjur, West Java province, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Gambling’s Spread
item.description: The popularity of sports betting has exploded in recent years in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lobbyists kept tabs on sports betting legislation in Kansas in April.

item.title: UN Inspectors Report New Shelling Damage at Zaporizhzhia Plant
item.description: While there were no immediate safety concerns, the head of the U.N. nuclear watchdog said the scope of the damage “demonstrates the sheer intensity of the attacks on one of the world’s largest nuclear power plants.”
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in August.

item.title: Would You Pay $1,000 to See the World’s Biggest Lizards?
item.description: Indonesia wants to make it vastly more expensive to see the country’s famous Komodo dragons. The local tourism industry is up in arms.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:description: One of the many Komodo dragons that roam free in Komodo National Park in Indonesia.

item.title: Inside the Saudi Strategy to Keep the World Hooked on Oil
item.description: The kingdom is working to keep fossil fuels at the center of the world economy for decades to come by lobbying, funding research and using its diplomatic muscle to obstruct climate action.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Iman Al-Dabbagh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A solar farm at the King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center in Riyadh, the Saudi capital.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A nightclub shooting in Colorado kills five.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: There did not appear to be any prior threats to Club Q before the shooting, the Colorado Springs police chief said on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine Plans Evacuations in Kherson and Mykolaiv
item.description: The government is making plans to evacuate residents who want to leave from Kherson and Mykolaiv, where fighting has badly damaged the infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians in Kherson gathering for food aid on Saturday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The World Cup Kicks Off
item.description: Plus COP27 ends with a landmark deal and Twitter reinstates Donald Trump’s account.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Ecuador’s Enner Valencia celebrated scoring their second goal with teammates at Al Bayt Stadium in Al Khor, Qatar, on Sunday.

item.title: Canada Imposes Sanctions on Haiti’s Former Leader and Other Officials
item.description: Among the six targeted over possible ties to criminal gangs were former President Michel Martelly and two former prime ministers.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Haitian police officers at a checkpoint in a gang-controlled area of Port-au-Prince, the capital, last year.

item.title: Videos Suggest Captive Russian Soldiers Were Killed at Close Range
item.description: Videos circulating online and reported on by Russian state media have raised questions about whether Ukrainian soldiers committed a war crime.
item.dc:creator: Malachy Browne, Stephen Hiltner, Chevaz Clarke-Williams and Taylor Turner
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Inmates Who Killed a Writer and a Publisher Escape in Bangladesh
item.description: Men convicted of fatally stabbing the Bangladeshi-American author Avijit Roy and his publisher fled custody in an unsettling reminder of extremist violence against intellectuals.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Zakir Hossain Chowdhury/NurPhoto via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mourning Avijit Roy in 2019 in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Mr. Roy, an author critical of religious extremism, was hacked to death by assailants with machetes as he left a book fair in 2015.

item.title: Turkey Bombs Kurdish Foes in Iraq and Syria, Likely Killing Dozens
item.description: Turkish officials said the airstrikes were a counterterrorism operation against militants it accused of bombing Istanbul last week.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Sangar Khaleel
item.media:description: Damage by Turkish airstrikes on Sunday in the Syrian village of Taql Baql, in Hasakeh Province.

item.title: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Endures More Shelling
item.description: The United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency called the strikes “extremely disturbing.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant last month.

item.title: At Least 437 Children Have Been Killed Since February, Ukraine says.
item.description: Andriy Kostin, Ukraine’s prosecutor general, said that the true numbers were likely to be far higher.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The aftermath of a deadly Russian missile attack in Vinnytsia, Ukraine, in July.

item.title: A Contentious World Cup
item.description: Concerns about corruption and human rights loom over a typically joyous sporting event.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Doha, Qatar.

item.title: At Least 5 Dead and 25 Injured in Gunman’s Rampage at an L.G.B.T.Q. Club in Colorado
item.description: The police said a suspect in the shooting, who was also injured, was arrested.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Mitch Smith, Adam Goldman and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Andrew Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evidence markers outside a 7-Eleven store near Club Q in Colorado Springs.

item.title: In Iraq’s Mountains, Iranian Opposition Fighters Feel the Squeeze
item.description: The armed groups, which have trained in the Kurdistan region for decades, face attacks from Iran and pressure from the Iraqi government to give up their weapons.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Sangar Khaleel and Emily Garthwaite

item.title: U.N. Climate Talks End With a Deal to Pay Poor Nations for Damage
item.description: Nations reached a landmark deal to compensate developing nations for climate harm. But some leaders said the summit didn’t go far enough in addressing the root causes of global warming.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, Max Bearak, Lisa Friedman and Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Sameh Shoukry, the Egyptian foreign minister, seated, reading a statement at the closing session of climate talks in Sharm el Sheikh.

item.title: As Climate Protests Get Bolder, British Police Strike Back With New Powers
item.description: New rules curtailing protests have alarmed some who fear an erosion of civil rights. They come as environmental protesters have intensified their tactics to draw attention to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Activists from the group Just Stop Oil being arrested last month for blocking a road in London.

item.title: Malaysian Election Adds New Turmoil: Hung Parliament
item.description: The country has been hit by a series of political shocks in recent years and now confronts the first hung Parliament in its history.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Lining up to vote in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Saturday. The government lowered the voting age in 2019, and a record number of voters cast ballots.
